memoize doesn't behave correctly with multi-argument functions
body:
The lodash memoize function seems to only work correctly with single-argument functions. If it's a multi-argument function it just memoizes based on the first argument and ignores the remaining arguments.

```
const _ = require('lodash');
const g = _.memoize((a, b) => a + b)
console.log(g(1, 2))
console.log(g(1, 3))
console.log(g(1, 4))
```

I expect the output to be 3 4 5

The output with lodash is 3 3 3

 If this behavior is by design I would expect that the docs would mention that lodash's memoize implementation doesn't work with multi-argument functions.

Should be:
    if (string.slice(0, end).search(separator)) {

title: Request for custom compare function support for min/max and minBy/maxBy functions.
body:
There is an implemented feature  #3763 for `orderBy` function, but it looks like there is nothing for `min`, `max`, `minBy` and `maxBy` functions.

Sure, you can initially sort the collection in the required order and then take the first element, but it is less efficient because new array will be allocated, whereas simple iteration should be enough.

Actually having `max` and `min` with custom compare functions covers `maxBy` and `minBy`.

title: isUndefined - use typeof instead?
body: Currently, the implementation for isUndefined uses a strict equality comparison with the value `undefined`. I was wondering why it was decided to use this method (that errors if the variable is undeclared) rather than using `typeof value === 'undefined'`, which doesn't. I have my theories but I'd be interested to hear from contributors!

title: Best way to use Lodash with react native
body:
Hello,

I see a lot of comparison on whether should I use `lodash`, `lodash-es` or `lodash/fp`.

- https://medium.com/making-internets/why-using-chain-is-a-mistake-9bc1f80d51ba
- or this one https://www.blazemeter.com/blog/the-correct-way-to-import-lodash-libraries-a-benchmark/

----
**Beside the fact I'm totally lost with all of this, depending on having webpack plugin, babel plugin…**, especially on the web where the bundle size matters.

I would like to ask you what is the advantage of using any of those, because shipped within react native we don't really care much about some small more ko of the bundle.

The only difference I could see is in terms of loading time (but is it really game changer depending on the bundle ?)

**What do you recommend me for React native usage?**

I really appreciate the fact of using lodash chain method, I saw some tutorials with `flow` and `fp`?

Thanks a lot

title: Behaviour of _.isEmpty, _.size with ArrayBuffer and SharedArrayBuffer

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hello,

it wasn't immediately clear to me why my code using `SharedArrayBuffer` was behaving strangely and I was scratching my head.

`ArrayBuffer` and `SharedArrayBuffer` simply don't have a `length` property which seems to make `_.isEmpty` or `_.size` not behave as expected.

They have a `byteLength` property which is the actual size of the buffer but I don't understand why a `length` property is not in the spec while every other array like object has it.

Thus, `_.isEmpty` and `_.size` don't behave as would be expected from them on these objects, always returning `true` and `0` respectively.

I think these functions should be in line with what they return for `Buffer` or `Uint8Array`.

References : 
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/SharedArrayBuffer


In fact there is no `lodash.fp.min.js` in recent version.

Is there any methods to use both `lodash` and `lodash/fp` from CDN like jsDelivr? It could be better if `lodash.min.js` bundles with fp functions since it does not introduce much size to wrap a fp.

title: Opening this issue to know the state of the tests in lodash source code as they seems to be broken.
body:
We took a look at a few files in the test directory without the **.test.js** suffix and they seem to have problems that stopped them from running:

- test/__proto__-property-bugs.js: will error on line 48 (groupBy) because the second parameter being passed is a string and groupBy is expecting a function.
- test/ary.js: will error on line 4 because ../ary.js file does not exist.
- test/assignIn.js: will error on line 2 because ../extend.js file does not exist.

In fact, many of the files that contain tests that don't have the **.test.js** suffix appear to be broken (which we assume is why they don't have the suffix). For example, **compact.js** will error with identity is not defined because no variable is defined before it is used on line 32.

I am attaching a screenshot of one of the failing test to better explain the issue.


![Capture1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8237463/69210870-3e791c80-0b82-11ea-956d-2ac3ba6d65f0.PNG)

title: Proposal to add a new method getPath
handle emoji flag tag sequence

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Noticed that the emoji flag tag sequences are not handled correctly by `toArrray`. 

This updates the emoji regex to allow for an emoji sequence of the following form:

```
emoji_tag_sequence := tag_base tag_spec tag_term
tag_base           := emoji_character
                    | emoji_modifier_sequence
                    | emoji_presentation_sequence
tag_spec           := [\x{E0020}-\x{E007E}]+
tag_term           := \x{E007F}
```

This handles the generic emoji tag sequence defined in the [Unicode Technical Standard](https://unicode.org/reports/tr51/#def_emoji_tag_sequence) instead of only the specific currently valid emoji tag sequences [here](https://unicode.org/reports/tr51/#valid-emoji-tag-sequences).

[Feature Request] Showing Time Complexity of Functions In The Documentation
body:
I would like to know the time complexity (e.g. in Big O notation) of the algorithms, preferably in the documentation.

One of the cases is the differences of the time complexities between `sortedUniq` and `uniq`. My ultimate goal is to display an array of `String` with 1) no duplicates and 2) is sorted. And there are 2 ways to do so.
1. Sort the array, then apply `sortedUniq`
2. Apply `uniq` then sort the array

Currently, there is no way I know which one is better since I have no idea how "optimize" is `sortedUniq`. (For `uniq`, I assume it is `O(n)`)

title: Weird behavior with `set()`
Improve tree-shaking
body:
Hello! I have read, then tested tree-shaking with Angular 8 and `ng build --prod`.
I claim that tree shaking works not very well. If I import like this

    import {concat} from 'lodash';

the whole library imports. That is not very good. To import only 1 function `concat` I should write

    import concat from 'lodash/concat'

It is okay if I need only 1 function. but what if I need 2 or 10 of them? The code looks then extremely ugly.

I suggest to improve the module sysytem and import in casual way like 

     import {concat, map, filter, whatever} from 'lodash';

title: Sanitize sourceURL so it cannot affect evaled code
body:
Wherever it comes from, `sourceURL` should not be allowed to contain code that gets eval()-ed.

`/\s/` should cover all the bases as far as I know, including the various unicode-y ways of encoding newlines.

```
> sourceURL = '\u2028\u2029\nconsole.log("o hai")'
'  \nconsole.log("o hai")'
> eval('//# sourceURL=' + sourceURL)
o hai
undefined
> eval('//# sourceURL=' + sourceURL.replace(/\s/g, ' '))
undefined
```

title: Prevent prototype pollution chaining to code execution via _.template, part 2

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This is a followup to #4355 which unfortunately was incomplete, because of …

```
options = assignInWith({}, options, settings, customDefaultsAssignIn);
```

... which happens prior to the `hasOwnProperty` guard would merge in whatever happens to be on the prototype into `options`, so it'd all be considered as part of `options` "own" properties. That might be a bug in `assignInWith`, it's not clear whether that's intentional behaviour.

My testing focused on the `sourceURL` part (which was easier to inject with than `variable`), and it got stopped by the newline stripping. The newline stripping was also incomplete, as you can provide a unicode newline.

I added a utility to get a property without looking at the prototype, which I guess might be a bit too much for this PR. Happy to remove that, but I think it'd be nice to have a utility like that in lodash. :)

title: Document matches* shorthands for over* methods (#4510)
body:
In this commit I documented the shorthands added in #2193.

Additionally I updated documentation of `_.matches` and `_.matchesProperty` with hints on how to combine predicates.

Also I have hinted on combining the predicates in the documentation of `_.filter`, arguably the most used iterator.

Open questions:

1. Is it really possible to combine different types of shorthands?
1. How exactly should the JSDoc `@param` be updated for `over*` methods?
1. Are you happy with the placement of hints in the documentation?

title: Own toString method of wrapped functions (like allPass result) breaks redux-saga work
body:
Hi. I create issue to redux-saga: appPass result not working as pattern for takeEvery/takeLatest etc.

Answer of redux-saga contributor: https://github.com/redux-saga/redux-saga/issues/1950#issuecomment-539390080

In a nutshell, redux-saga check own toString method for work with libraries like redux-actions, which create action creators like:
```javascript
const testAction = foo => ({ type: 'TEST', foo }); 
testAction.toString = () => 'TEST';
``` 

I used allPass and it return function with own property `toString`.

Please explain why result of functions like allPass has redefined `toString` method? Thanks.

title: The document is too long
body: The official doc is too long, and always stuck in my browser :(

title: Document that over* methods accept matches* shortcuts
body:
I was pleasantly surprised that `filter` and others can use multiple matchers thanks to `over*` functions:

```javascript
_.filter(input, _.overSome([
    _.matches({'a': 1}),
    _.matches({'a': 2}),
]))
```

Thanks to #2193 this becomes even better:

```javascript
_.filter(input, _.overSome([
    {'a': 1},
    {'a': 2},
]))
```

However that last improvement seems to be undocumented. Could you please document this possibility for `over*` functions? Referring to them in the `matches` documentation could be the cherry on top.

title: Fix an issue where _.pick makes multiple calls to property getter

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Fixes https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4491

@jdalton [suggested](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4491#issuecomment-536827117) that this is a breaking change:

> Commit it against master. That's where all the breaking changes can occur.

I'm not sure this is a breaking change. The Lodash docs don't make any guarantees about when reads occur, so this is arguably just fixing a performance regression.

I can't figure out how to build/run the master branch (see issue notes), so I've tentatively opened this PR against `4.17.15-post`.  The priority is to fix this for Lodash 4, since that's the version we just upgraded to, and Lodash 5 is unreleased.

If someone could provide some contributor guidance, that would be great.

title: Fix issue where _getTag() fails with "TypeError: Expected at least one argument"

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Fixes https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4500

On PlayStation 4 and LG WebOS 2, the `Promise.require()` API throws an exception if the argument list is empty.  This causes the application to crash, because the Lodash bundle fails to evaluate.

The fix is to call `Promise.resolve(undefined)` instead.  This is the same solution used by https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/issues/396.

title: _getTag() fails with "TypeError: Expected at least one argument"
body:
When loading Lodash 4.17.15 on PlayStation 4's WebMAF runtime, I get this error:

```
Other 0.0.0 (Other) ERROR
  TypeError: Expected at least one argument
  at http://10.16.114.102:3100/lib/js/lodash/_getTag.js:34
```

The problematic code is here:
[_getTag.js](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.15-npm/_getTag.js#L37)
```js
// Fallback for data views, maps, sets, and weak maps in IE 11 and promises in Node.js < 6.
if ((DataView && getTag(new DataView(new ArrayBuffer(1))) != dataViewTag) ||
    (Map && getTag(new Map) != mapTag) ||
    (Promise && getTag(Promise.resolve()) != promiseTag) ||  <====
    (Set && getTag(new Set) != setTag) ||
    (WeakMap && getTag(new WeakMap) != weakMapTag)) {
```
This may be the same issue as https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3208 which was closed earlier.

body: Backport of https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/4496 to 4.17

title: Short circuit sortedIndexBy methods for empty arrays
body: I have a use case that involves building many smallish sorted arrays so I'm using `sortedIndexBy` as part of an insertion sort logic. As empty arrays are a common condition for me, I figured I should reach out and see if we could get them short circuited. Cheers.

title: Add _.getWith function
body: Takes customizer to customize values retrieved from _.get

title: sortedUniqWith
body:
There exists `uniq`, `uniqBy`, `uniqWith` but only `sortedUniq` and `sortedUniqBy`.

The sortedUniq* functions do not take a comparator, and instead run an `eq` (===) comparison.  I have a need for a custom comparator.

title: lodash.merge v4.6.2 does not get installed
body:
OS: Windows
Not able to install v4.6.2. At the same time V4.6.1 works.
tried with multiple systems and see the same result.
tried all the options of cleaning cache, deleting folders...

Throws 
npm ERR! code EINTEGRITY
npm ERR! sha512-0KpjqXRVvrYyCsX1swR/XTK0va6VQkQM6MNo7PqW77ByjAhoARA8EfrP1N4+KlKj8YS0ZUCtRT/YUuhyYDujIQ== integrity checksum failed when using sha512: wanted sha512-0KpjqXRVvrYyCsX1swR/XTK0va6VQkQM6MNo
7PqW77ByjAhoARA8EfrP1N4+KlKj8YS0ZUCtRT/YUuhyYDujIQ== but got sha512-y7f4VpFmgr4zZ3Q7Qfv6G/DKusIXKv5qgRPq7DeAwgX7B726i5AcjVcQQYtud7dOY4yYLgkyCuu1kUPfOMTGYA==. (864 bytes)
